segments.text: by others to ride along, and one fellow took quantitative bottom samples, so I became familiar with the, not only with the techniques, but also with the ideas behind it.
That is all to say that I did not become a pure plantologist, but did have one foot on the ground, figuratively speaking.

And finally, during these years, and also, and I really, during these years, I mean since 49, and also after 55, after the degree, during the postdoc time, I participated in Cry's expeditions, which were concerned with production biology of plankton, and in part conducted the work for him when he fell ill or whatever it was.
Cry had been interested in
in the rapid determination of plankton, particularly phytoplankton.
And rapid means rapid in contrast to the microscopical work.

What he wanted to achieve is to work with hydrographers who take salinity and temperature samples, which can be, of course, easily determined, and somehow assess the amount of plankton in effect in chemical ways.
He was the first to develop a sea-going chlorophyll method in 1939.

He then, which of course only goes for the plants, and he then tried to develop a method for the total plankton and thought of filtering of the total plankton out of the water sample of a liter or five liters out of a water bottle over filters and thought that would give him the total amount of plankton and the chlorophyll would allow him to subtract the phytoplankton
We know now that he developed the Cestan method.

What he essentially determined in coastal waters was, well, not in coastal waters, what he determined was the total particulate matter, which in coastal waters is phytoplanktonal aride, so planktonal aride, but also a lot of inorganic material.
So his method we call now Cestan method, and it was really his first student, Gilbrich, who pointed that out to him.
that, dear teacher, you are all wrong.

But he took it gracefully, and in the 50s was the scientist in the marine domain who pointed out to the rest of the world that most of the particulate matter and seawater in many, many places is not living, isn't plankton, and you geologists better do this and do that if you want to study the particulate matter and seawater.

Well, and later on, when realizing that he didn't get at the zooplankton by just weighing, he developed a method for determination of protein, or albumin, as he called it, again thinking, well, albumin or protein decays relatively soon after the death of the organism, so if I know the total protein content in a sample and know also the chlorophyll content, then I probably could figure out the zooplankton.
And these methods could be run on board ships.
So two or three days after taking the samples, I already have the result and can plan my further expedition accordingly, which was a very modern idea.
couldn't quite execute it, but that is a different story.

At any rate, by participating in these expeditions, I became familiar with the methods, but perhaps more importantly also with his way of looking at the world to take a hydrographic cast first, to determine salinity and temperature first, and then decide what biological samples to take, which most pathologists and sociologists didn't do.
but that was the characteristic of his school to really tie in with the hydrography.
And that is what I really learned from Krai.
And the exposure to this kind of doing plankton research and I should really interject, his samples were taken again
from water bottles, that means from point samples, and not from nets.
Remember the argument about the plankton pump.
So the way of sampling lent itself more easily to close cooperation with the physical types.
But then Kai was not in chemistry, he wasn't a biologist, so he did not scoff at looking at the microscope.
We were trained to know animals.
And as I said earlier, I have counted 1,000 animal samples, too.

but we were a little unusual by having this extra exposure, which was reinforced by Wst, who was the director of the institute, who entirely was interested in working on the Atlantic, rather than the keel bay, because he felt he was the legitimate heir to the meteor expedition,
and tried to publish all what was still to be published on the big German Atlantic expedition on meteoroid during the 20s.

So that all the lectures in physical oceanography were about the Atlantic, the open ocean, rather than the local waters, which is a little unusual for a coastal station to be told always about the open ocean, never about the home water.
They didn't know anything about keel waves.

And on the expeditions in the North Sea with CHI and, well, North Sea, the physical oceanographers we met also all came out of the Meteor School, so that the CHI students got, I think, quite an unusual training for coming out of a small institution, a coastal institution.
In Woods Hole and Scripps, it goes without saying, but in Chesapeake Bay, it wouldn't be this way.
And this sort of slant is, I think, still reflected in my way of teaching on the upper-division level.
And of course, my students, the graduates too, but on the undergraduate level, I think I teach differently from most other oceanography schools or marine biology schools.
I will come back to this point later.
So to sum it up, we were

In regard to the research on the biology of marine organisms, we were trained, now let me back up, to sum this up once more, we were trained by Kryan, by Wst, really as biological oceanographers, and in effect learned
not to concern ourselves with the biology of marine organisms as a subject of its own, but only as a means to understand the ocean better.
So that is then 55 now.
Subsequently, I couldn't get a position because there were no permanent positions around in Germany.
German equivalent of NSF began to see the light and set out postdoc positions.
They wanted to begin to build up staff and they realized they had to do something for the young people.
So I received a postdoc award for three years.
took with tenure in Kiel to work along a proposal of my own to study the distribution, the vertical distribution of copepods, crustaceans, in the Kiel Bay, essentially.
And the idea came from working on these dissertation samples where I had kept an eye on the other animals too, without really making notes, but sort of
had acquired a feel that the notion that copy-puts migrate, what every textbook said, there's diurnal migrations, didn't really hold.
They didn't apparently migrate.
And I proposed to the science foundation, let's investigate that, using these same samples we had already.
So it was, in a way, a relatively cheap investigation.
And I could, in fact, show that there is no vertical migration to speak of in these waters.
And I also could show by study of literature that this had to do with the salinity stratification.

And the result then is that the vertical distribution of these organisms, where you find them, in which depths you find them, had not so much to do with what the elements liked, but where the currents brought them, the currents and the mixing.
And this, of course, very contrary to what in those years, at least every

textbook said, including marine, so-called oceanography textbooks, they all implied that the animals, of course, you find the animals at that depth which they like most, by just migrating up and downwards.
And I could show this is not so.
And because of the, it is not so in Kiel Bay, and I could advance reasons that because of

because the salinity stratification exists in many marginal seas, on many shelves, that it was likely that at least the smaller copepodes would not migrate there either, even in the upper mixed layer.
And I guess in hindsight that this was said at least 10 or 15, or maybe by now 20 years too early, because nobody has really picked that up yet.
And I have not been shown to be wrong.
So it is still hanging, so to speak.
And most people can't find it because they still use nets, with a few exceptions.
And the net is towed through the mixed layer, and well, it's all the planters mixed up in one bucket.
And so you can't say what they do.
I will come back to this a little later because at the end, really, of that period in 1958, I begin to think about the problems of the mixed layer and the plankton distribution in the mixed layer.
And as I said, I will come back to this later.
But during these three years, which I consider to be really the most pleasant period of my professional life, I was already something.
I had a Ph.D. degree, had also a reasonable income, but I had practically no obligations.
So I had the best of both worlds, in a way.
During these years, I did a few other things, too.
As I had said earlier, I had participated in CRI's expeditions and in part conducted some of these, and so wrote my own papers on production biology, a la CRI.
which was strictly concerned with concentrations.
Rate measurements were not discovered by us, so to speak.
And I also began to work on polycate taxonomy.
I wrote a few papers on, really made revisions of some genera of benthic polycates, sabellites, which are still in interest, which I still have.
And again, I will come back to that later.
Yeah, and that is really the end of the training period, because in a way then post-doc is still in training period.
By that time I had

already crossed the bridge in the sense of that I did not pursue the teacher career and began to gamble now on that there would be a university career, much to the dismay of my father, who had paid through 1955 and who had said, well, had you chosen economics, the bet would have been made, more or less, and you would be something now, meaning something already a university professor, possibly, or something in the free enterprise system.
But before I go on, let me explain the ordinary way one entered into a university career.
One took the PhD degree and then had to wait for what we would call an instructor position to become available.

then became an instructor with some teaching duties but not much but the main idea being now to show to prove oneself by doing independent independent scientific work for five or up to ten years and then write a second second thesis which is still the way it's being done in sweden in italy and russia too so the really the second phd degree
allowing you to enter the university career.
That's quite different from here.
So I had to come up now with a very thick other tone entirely of my own.
And if you want to switch that off now, that would be the timing.
So the question then was now what subject to tackle?
And in oceanography, of course, that means not only having the idea, but also having the logistics behind you.
Would somebody take you along on a ship, or would you get on a ship, and what have you.
And Krai said, well,
What is coming up now on the international scene is the IGY, the International Geophysical Year.
We, Germany, that is, will invest into it, and this is your chance.
Participate in a large expedition, gather very comprehensive material, and be sort of assured of funds for working it up.
And never mind that you don't have an instructor position.
You will have money to work that up.
And I suggest that you work on the total phosphorus.
And I thought it was just absolutely against my interest.
First of all, there came up this chemist issue again.
I would be again labeled a chemist.
But also, I thought there was no issue to be solved, no major question to be solved by this total post-war business.
And therefore, decided to pursue, to take up again in plan I had had earlier.
to work on the plankton of the tropical ocean.
And to make that a little more clear, I would have to back up for a moment and say that in my mind the most comprehensive plankton study ever made is that by Lohmann, who published in 1908.
And that, in a way, is still the best Planckman study ever, except now that he couldn't, in those years, measure the rate.
He only measured concentrations.
But it was the most comprehensive study up until now, 1977, three quarters of a century later.

One of the contributions by Lohmann being showing how important it is to look at the small plankton, phytoplankton and zooplankton, that nets are inappropriate tools for collecting even zooplankton, if you wanted to know the total metabolism of the water column.
That study of Lohmann's had been done in Kiel, and my idea was to repeat that study in the tropical ocean.
And I had begun to look for an appropriate site a few years earlier when Nod, whom I had mentioned as somebody sharing my room, had gone to El Salvador in, I don't know, 54 or 55.
But at that time, there was an exchange program between El Salvador and Germany, but their condition was you have to have the PhD, which I didn't.
So El Salvador fell through, and in hindsight, it is good because I would have had to work in estuaries, and I wouldn't have managed to.
I was not equipped to work.
My training was too weak to face the plankton estuaries, really, to make some good story out of it.

The next attempt was to go to Brazil, and again, there was an exchange program where Gerlach, whom I had mentioned before, had gone and had studied nematodes on Brazilian beaches, but that fell through because I had written to the Brazilians that I would need such and such instruments and I would
hope that they would provide it, and I would bring this and this and that.
And could they please write whether they have 110 voltage or 220?
And when they were unable to answer that simple question, 110 or 220, I thought, well, better not.
I knew of Hawaii, but that was out of reach because of cost, because of the very unfavorable conversion rate from Deutsche Mark to Hawaii.
the dollar.
I didn't know of Bermuda, where there was a very good current, very good program going on under Reith and Menzel.

So I settled on India, where, again, exchange program, that is always a problem, or was a problem, how to finance such a stay on my own, because I sort of had told Kai, I don't want to go with you, and so Kai sort of was not angry, but
somehow didn't feel obliged to now go out on a limb and ask for extra money in addition to financing his own expeditions.
So I had to find my own money, in effect, and so India was the next place which seemed quite all right because India was moderately advanced as compared with Africa, say.
Remember, I wanted to go to the tropics rather than to the temperate Africa, warm, temperate Africa, South Africa.
There was nothing in the tropical Africa, and in America there was nothing either after Brazil
didn't come to pass.
I'd never thought of the Caribbean, I don't know why.

At any rate, so that was then India, and they offered a two-year exchange, which anyway seemed very good because I thought of a seasonal study and figured that the first half year would be wasted by this or by that, and I would get going only then after six months, and I wanted to have a little overlap, means six plus 15 months is already 21 months, so two years seemed just right.

And so I began to prepare for that, prepare proposals, and also learn about the carbon-14 method because that became known at that time through Stema Nielsen's efforts and gave a new dimension, really, to the question about the tropical ocean.
Should I continue?
Sure.
I went to, I participated in a course on the carbon-fault technique by Simon Edison, so I got in.
I learned all the tricks from the grand man himself and of course also became a little indoctrinated in the good sense of the word.

I could participate in the Bergen Symposium in 1957, fall of 57, which was the first meeting by people working on productivity with a new tool and exchanging ideas, and it was an enormously successful, important milestone, a very successful symposium and a really important milestone in phytoplankton oceanography, so to speak.
where I learned about the Bermuda results.
Reiser told me about it and said, well, had I known, we could have invited you to Bermuda, which was too late, of course.
But at any rate, I benefited very greatly from what I learned at that meeting, what Reiser told me.
And then in early 1958, went to India to work on the tropical ocean.
That was the subject.
Seasonal study.
in place.
The tropical ocean, of course, by definition has no seasons, but I wanted to repeat Lohmann's work cast into more modern terms.
Now, without going into all the detail, I state largely in Cochin, what is now known as Cochin on the southwest coast of India, but run into many difficulties of a technical term.
Working conditions, for example, were very difficult.
In effect, I had to do a lot of chemical work, starting from salinity, titrations, through nutrient analysis, into chlorophyll determination, and of course phytoplankton counting, too.
But for all these two years, I didn't have running water.
But I had to do chemistry out of water buckets, and not even enough water in the dry season.
So it was really very difficult to do.
Another difficulty was that the research vessel, which was run by a Norwegian aid project, was out of commission for seven out of 12 months.
And of course, if you make a seasonal study, it is a little difficult.
Five months on a stretch, that vessel was not available.
So I had to make do with other vessels or bottoms.
Then there was a general attitude by the Indian researchers
It was not very easy.
Of course, to live there in those years was not easy either.
Not only no air condition, but no refrigerator even, and loneliness.
So it was not very happy years.
I forgot to mention, among the sort of objective difficulties, owing to a slight mistake by
by a clerk at the Indian Embassy in Bonn, I could not get hold of my scientific luggage, which were five crates, for five months.
So for five months, they were just sitting in the customs and couldn't be released.
And it took them five months to straighten out that red tape.
And during these five months, well, there's some good always, of course.
During these five months, I read the literature, the local literature, which I had not had time to do beforehand.
In a way, I went a little unprepared, which I have found out later most people do.
They have said, yeah, and then they have to do so many other things that they don't have time to read about, not only about the Hindu festivals, but also about the ordinary oceanography.

But in addition, of course, by being at the place, I could read the local literature, which was in sort of gray literature or manuscripts not yet published and papers by the Department of Fisheries and what have you, which all contained original data, so that I had lots of original data and could plot, and I had enough time to plot all these, and they all didn't hang together.
It was very, very strange, and I couldn't make sense of it.
But then when I made my first cruise in August of 58, then it suddenly fell into place.
This was upwelling.
that was in effect, not in effect, I did discover one of the major upwelling regions of the globe.
All the southwest, all the west coast of India is a major upwelling area, which nobody had known before, which of course took care of the idea of working in the, the typical tropical ocean.
It wasn't typical.
It was a strongly seasonal upwelling region, but of course it was interesting enough.
I published on this right away, of course, but in hindsight it was in the wrong place, in the wrong journal.
It was about the hydrography of fisheries, I believe, of the southwest coast of India, published in a first issue of a new biological journal.
It came out in 59, and none of the people who went on to the Indian Ocean Expedition two years later had read that paper.

so that all the ships working in the ocean stopped sampling when they crossed the Indian Shelf, because everybody knew nothing went on on the Indian Shelf, and all the exciting parts, the exciting regions, the western side of the Arabian Sea.
And up to this day, no physical oceanography work of any quality has been done on the Indian Shelf, because afterwards the Suez Canal was closed, and so...

Well, as I said, I published in the- made a very meritorious publication, I'm still very proud of, but because it was published at the- in the wrong place and perhaps in the wrong- at the wrong time to- that was it.
Had I gone to a congress, of course, and had given speeches, it would have been different, but of course I couldn't get from there to New York.
Now, yeah, had I gone to a congress,
There was a big Congress in 1959, the first international Congress on Oceanography held in New York, to which I couldn't go.
But at that Congress, the Department of Oceanography here in Seattle

began to look around for a new biologist because their biological oceanographer had not panned out, had not published and had to go after his six years, was not promoted, and so they wanted to replace him.
And Ratri, who happens now to be chairman, talked around and asked, do you know somebody, and ran into Krai, and Krai said, sure, I have somebody who's in India and who might be interested.
And so I got the advertisement, and would I be interested to apply?

and to cut this story short I did apply because in Germany there was still no position and although I was sort of assured that I wouldn't have to starve it was clear that in order to enter the university career I would still have many many years of waiting without lecturing without well just work on my own and I thought I was not old enough to shoulder responsibility and perhaps begin lecturing and so I wrote to Seattle and

said, yes, I would like to apply, but since I had burned my fingers in India so badly, I didn't want to go right away, sign my contract while still in India, but suggested, asked, could I come over and look at the situation over, and that suited them eminently because they, of course, didn't want to buy somebody either whom they had never seen.
So immediately after returning from India in spring of 1960, I went here for six weeks and liked it very much.
And they liked me too, and so that was it.
And I appeared on the scene here in autumn of 1960.
The reason why I came here was the unsatisfactory situation in Germany.

But more importantly, the positive aspect that the philosophy here, the definition of oceanography, which is really due to Barnes, Fleming, and Barnes and Rattray, was very much the one I was used to.
It was not marine biology or biology of marine organisms, but it was really oceanography.
And they offered me a position of responsibility and I also could enter the teaching career right away.
So it was really more the positive aspect than the fact that in Germany I would just have to do research, continue to do research.
But the upshot was that because of all the duties piled upon me, the plankton work from the Indian Ocean was never published.
All the samples had been counted, all the analysis done, but I had never had time to publish, which is sad in a way.
But I had never had the three months or so which I would have needed to publish.
So that is still there.
Are you ready to begin the Seattle career?
Yes.
OK.
